rationale: 'severe-to-moderate' describes impact/illness, not an intensified risk-adjective describing the virus.
statement_text: First, you have to have a confirmed case in a human of a respiratory-transmitted virus that then resulted in severe-to-moderate respiratory illness—and then you just start picking up additional human cases in that area.

rationale: 'severe-to-moderate respiratory illness' describes symptoms, not using Q2 high-potency language.
statement_text: First, you have to have a confirmed case in a human of a respiratory-transmitted virus that then resulted in severe-to-moderate respiratory illness—and then you just start picking up additional human cases in that area.

rationale: The verbs 'resulted' and 'picking up' are not on the list of moderate verbs for this rule.
statement_text: First, you have to have a confirmed case in a human of a respiratory-transmitted virus that then resulted in severe-to-moderate respiratory illness—and then you just start picking up additional human cases in that area.
